content: The "Systemic Risk Designation Improvement Act of 2013" amends the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act by revising the table of contents and enhancing the authority of the Council to supervise certain nonbank financial companies and bank holding companies. The "Systemic Risk Designation Improvement Act of 2013" enhances the Council's authority to supervise nonbank financial companies and bank holding companies. Amendments include requiring enhanced supervision and regulation of certain entities. The "Systemic Risk Designation Improvement Act of 2013" grants the Council authority to subject bank holding companies to enhanced supervision and standards if their activities could threaten US financial stability. The Council considers indicators like company size, interconnectedness, and global activity when making this determination. The "Systemic Risk Designation Improvement Act of 2013" grants the Council authority to subject bank holding companies to enhanced supervision and standards based on indicators like company size, interconnectedness, and global activity. Amendments include changes in subsections (d) and (e) through (j) to address the complexity of bank holding companies and nonbank financial companies. The Dodd-Frank Act is amended to enhance supervision of bank holding companies, with changes in subsections (a) and (b) to differentiate between different types of companies. The amendments aim to address the complexity of bank holding companies and nonbank financial companies. The Dodd-Frank Act is amended to enhance supervision of bank holding companies by expanding the sections of the Act that apply to them. This includes changes in subsections (a), (b), and (c) of section 113, as well as amendments to sections 116, 121, and 155 regarding final determinations and mitigation measures for companies under scrutiny. The Dodd-Frank Act is amended to enhance supervision of bank holding companies by expanding the sections of the Act that apply to them. Specifically, subsection (d) is amended by removing the requirement for total consolidated assets of $50 billion or more and replacing it with a final determination under section 113. The Dodd-Frank Act is amended to enhance supervision of bank holding companies by expanding the sections of the Act that apply to them. Specifically, subsection (d) is amended by removing the requirement for total consolidated assets of $50 billion or more and replacing it with a final determination under section 113. Additionally, revisions to board authority are made. The Dodd-Frank Act is amended to enhance supervision of bank holding companies by expanding the sections of the Act that apply to them. This includes amendments to sections 163, 164, and 165, replacing the asset threshold requirement with a final determination under section 113.
